title: $A stabilises after yuan hits 4-year low
text:
Print 
The Australian dollar has recovered the losses caused by China's decision to weaken its currency. 
At 1700 AEST on Thursday, the currency was trading at 73.62 US cents, up from 72.62 cents on Wednesday. 
Despite a third yuan devaluation by China's central bank in as many days, taking it to a four year low, the Aussie had largely stabilised, National Australia Bank global co-head of FX strategy Ray Attrill said. 
The Australian dollar suffered one US cent falls on each of the previous days, but shook off the latest action in China on Thursday, to be close to Monday's levels. 
"It was helped by the fact that Chinese authorities have made clear they don't expect to see (the yuan) continuing on a path of trend weakness," Mr Attrill said. 
At 1700 AEST, the Australian dollar was at 91.66 Japanese yen, up from Wednesday's close of 90.61 yen, and at 66.18 euro cents, up from 65.53 euro cents. 
The Australian bond market weakened amid volatile trading amid China's latest currency fix. 
"Usually that's spurred a risk-off move with US dollar world bid, bonds rallying, equities coming off - and we've got the reverse of that today," JP Morgan interest rate strategist Sally Auld said. 
"I don't know how you make sense of that." 
Ms Auld said Thursday night's release of US retail sales data will be a key event for the markets. 
There is fears China's currency shifts will prevent the US Federal Reserve from hiking interest rates in September as expected, she said. 
"If we get soft data that will only serve to cement that view," Ms Auld said. 
At 1630 AEST on Thursday, the September 2015 10-year bond futures contract was trading at 97.230 (implying a yield of 2.770 per cent), down from 97.305 (2.695 per cent) on Wednesday. 
The September 2015 three-year bond futures contract was at 98.060 (1.940 per cent), down from 98.120 (1.880 per cent). @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Atlas Iron sufferes $1.4b loss AAP
